content.raw:
Not sure if it is related, but `CMAKE_DL_LIBS` is empty on Windows, as the `dlfcn.h` is not provided by any system library, but rather by the [`dlfcn-win32`](https://github.com/dlfcn-win32/dlfcn-win32) library. 
If you are using a recent version of dlfcn-win32, you can just search for its CMake package and link its imported target (see https://github.com/dlfcn-win32/dlfcn-win32/pull/40/files). Otherwise it seems that currently it is searched in #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/annotate/b6e82be45de9134d69ee9ad9ae5f4a50aaed7d10/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake?at=FixWindows_tolower&fileviewer=file-view-default#SearchForStuff.cmake-86 .
content.html: Not sure if it is related, but CMAKE_DL_LIBS is empty on Windows, as the dlfcn.h is not provided by any system library, but rather by the dlfcn-win32 library. If you are using a recent version of dlfcn-win32, you can just search for its CMake package and link its imported target (see https://github.com/dlfcn-win32/dlfcn-win32/pull/40/files). Otherwise it seems that currently it is searched in #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/annotate/b6e82be45de9134d69ee9ad9ae5f4a50aaed7d10/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake?at=FixWindows_tolower&fileviewer=file-view-default#SearchForStuff.cmake-86 .

content.raw:
That could explain some things.

Do we know what the cmake variable name would be once that `find_library` routine is finished? I don't think we're invoking it yet in any of our calls to `target_link_libraries`. I'm guessing that on Unix systems we're just getting lucky and some other Unix-only dependency is already linking to it, so we don't get this error on Linux or Mac.
content.html:

I'm guessing that on Unix systems we're just getting lucky and some other Unix-only dependency is already linking to it, so we don't get this error on Linux or Mac.

content.raw:
From what I understand from the CMake, it should be sufficient to just add: 
~~~cmake
target_include_directories(${PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME} PRIVATE ${libdl_include_dir})
target_link_libraries(${PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME} ${libdl_library})
~~~
I also don't understand why everything is working fine in *nix, perhaps there is some sort of transitive dependency in linking?
content.html:
From what I understand from the CMake, it should be sufficient to just add: 

target_include_directories(${PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME} PRIVATE ${libdl_include_dir})
target_link_libraries(${PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME} ${libdl_library})

I also don't understand why everything is working fine in *nix, perhaps there is some sort of transitive dependency in linking?

content.raw: `accommodate` and `sanitize` seem to behave somewhat complementary, yet their names don't say much about what they're doing. Consider giving them more descriptive names.
content.html: accommodate and sanitize seem to behave somewhat complementary, yet their names don't say much about what they're doing. Consider giving them more descriptive names.

content.raw: I totally agree, but these were the best I could come up with. I'm not really sure what words would make sense here. I feel like "sanitize" at least makes sense since it's sort of "cleaning" the symbols to match the most common standard, but I don't know what to use as a complementary name. "desanitize" seems like a bad choice.

"desanitize" seems like a bad choice.

content.raw: I'm not really convinced adding an option to print warnings to every function is a good idea, it sounds like the user should control this by setting the verbosity level.
content.html: I'm not really convinced adding an option to print warnings to every function is a good idea, it sounds like the user should control this by setting the verbosity level.

content.raw: That's reasonable, but I think sometimes a user might anticipate the possibility of a failure and not want it logged, even if the verbosity level matches their current settings, because they might want to handle the failure in their own way.
content.html: That's reasonable, but I think sometimes a user might anticipate the possibility of a failure and not want it logged, even if the verbosity level matches their current settings, because they might want to handle the failure in their own way.

content.raw: Makes sense. I guess one alternative ugly way to handle that could be wrapping the command on `SetVerbosity` calls. I just worry that if we add this to part of the API, it would only be consistent to add it to the whole API.
content.html: Makes sense. I guess one alternative ugly way to handle that could be wrapping the command on SetVerbosity calls. I just worry that if we add this to part of the API, it would only be consistent to add it to the whole API.

content.raw:
We're adding it to these functions that perform system calls on the filesystem, specifically because:

1. It's really annoying (and sometimes actually impossible) for an end-user to identify what went wrong inside of a function that is performing multiple system calls on the filesystem, so we should try to automatically provide helpful warnings, and

2. Sometimes users actually do want to do some goofy things with the filesystem and accept responsibility for parsing the errors without us intervening.

This PR has already added the option to all the APIs we offer that interact with the filesystem, so I don't think maintenance is going to be an issue.

That said, it occurs to me that a boolean is almost always a bad thing to use as a function argument because it's not very expressive, so I think I'd like to change this to an enumeration, such as

```
enum FilesystemWarningOp
{
  LOG_WARNINGS = 0,
  SUPPRESS_WARNINGS
};
```
content.html:
We're adding it to these functions that perform system calls on the filesystem, specifically because:

  1. It's really annoying (and sometimes actually impossible) for an end-user to identify what went wrong inside of a function that is performing multiple system calls on the filesystem, so we should try to automatically provide helpful warnings, and

  2. Sometimes users actually do want to do some goofy things with the filesystem and accept responsibility for parsing the errors without us intervening.

This PR has already added the option to all the APIs we offer that interact with the filesystem, so I don't think maintenance is going to be an issue.

That said, it occurs to me that a boolean is almost always a bad thing to use as a function argument because it's not very expressive, so I think I'd like to change this to an enumeration, such as

enum FilesystemWarningOp
{
  LOG_WARNINGS = 0,
  SUPPRESS_WARNINGS
};

content.raw: Ok fair enough, let's leave this in. We should also document the `_printWarnings` param on every function :wink:
content.html: Ok fair enough, let's leave this in. We should also document the _printWarnings param on every function

content.raw:
It's just wrapping up some Windows code that checks for error messages from the file system, because naturally Windows does things its own special way.

I'll change it to actually use `Console` instead of the plain `std::cerr`.
content.html:
It's just wrapping up some Windows code that checks for error messages from the file system, because naturally Windows does things its own special way.

I'll change it to actually use Console instead of the plain std::cerr.

content.raw: The [latest CI build of this branch](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/267/console) is very very close to succeeding. It's just running into a linker problem which is almost certainly related to a disagreement about the `/MD` and `/MT` flags between our library and some pre-built library that the CI is using. Unfortunately, I don't know a direct way to identify which library is the culprit, so this may require a little more grinding. Based on my understanding, I think we should strongly prefer using the `/MD` flag over the `/MT` flag, so we'll need to identify which library in the CI is using the `/MT` flag, and replace or rebuild it to use the `/MD` flag.
content.html: The latest CI build of this branch is very very close to succeeding. It's just running into a linker problem which is almost certainly related to a disagreement about the /MD and /MT flags between our library and some pre-built library that the CI is using. Unfortunately, I don't know a direct way to identify which library is the culprit, so this may require a little more grinding. Based on my understanding, I think we should strongly prefer using the /MD flag over the /MT flag, so we'll need to identify which library in the CI is using the /MT flag, and replace or rebuild it to use the /MD flag.
